awd_titl_txt: RoL:FELS:RAISE: Building and Modeling Synthetic Bacterial Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past century, biological research into how living cells function has led to advances in medicine, industry, and our understanding of what life is. Even with these extraordinary scientific discoveries, scientists still are far from understanding many of the first principals of cellular life. Synthetic Biology is a field that is an amalgam of molecular biology, biochemistry, computational science, and engineering. The rationale for this research is to fully understand how chemical components come together to make a living cell. This research may result in the construction of a bacterial cell from non-living parts. Recent work at the J. Craig Venter Institute produced a bacterial cell that had only a minimal set of genes necessary for life. The organism had only 474 genes and almost all were very similar to genes in the other organisms that live on Earth. Despite all of the advances of biological science, researchers still do not know the function of more than one third of those essential-for-life genes. The synthetic bacterial cells created through this project will catalyze an expansion of biological knowledge that may result in better health, improvements in biomanufacturing, new tools to preserve the environment, and other applications that will enhance the lives of humans everywhere. The rule of life to be investigated asks, on the molecular level, what are the necessary components of an organism that are required to call it alive? The researchers will use results of the experimental studies to develop theoretical frameworks for understanding the basic components and key elements of a living cell.

To build a synthetic cell this project will combine the expertise of three scientists from different fields. The project leader, John Glass, is a synthetic biologist and part of the Venter Institute team that constructed the minimal bacterial cell. Kate Adamala is a biochemist with expertise building non-living cell-like vesicles. Chris Kempes is a computational biologist who creates mathematical and computational models of living cells that will guide the selection the chemical parts that will be assembled. This team will combine a synthetic DNA genome capable of programming cell and cellular hardware such as enzymes, membranes, amino acids, salts, and vitamins in such a way as to form a bacterial cell.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Biotechnology has emerged as a pivotal force in American industry, giving rise to a diverse array of products, from pharmaceuticals to detergents. Many of these innovative products result from the genetic modification of microbes. Despite their engineered origins, these microbes draw on natural biochemical reactions to generate novel substances. Increasingly, genetic engineers are pushing the boundaries by constructing synthetic cells capable of producing chemicals unattainable through conventional microbes, owing to their potential toxicity to biological machinery.

The field of synthetic biology aims to create living synthetic cells from non-living components, a goal we endeavored to achieve in our project. Inspired by the groundbreaking work at the J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI), which successfully built a living bacterial cell with a synthetic genome in 2010, our plan centered on utilizing a similar approach. Specifically, we intended to employ mycoplasmas, the simplest bacteria on Earth, as the basis for our synthetic cells.

Collaborating with the University of Minnesota, we combined the JCVI's expertise in booting up cells with synthetic genomes with the Minnesota team's proficiency in crafting synthetic lipid vesicles—microscopic, bacteria-sized lipid bubbles. Our vesicles will encapsulate mycoplasma cell-free extracts, capable of in vitro mRNA transcription and protein translation. This fusion of technologies aimed to yield a living mycoplasma cell.

Regrettably, our project encountered a prolonged setback of nearly four years in attempting to establish a functioning cell-free extract in vitro transcription and translation system from mycoplasma cells. This unforeseen challenge, unique in its rarity, led to the publication of a paper detailing our unsuccessful efforts in 2022—a rare occurrence in scientific literature. Surprisingly, this candid account of our failures proved beneficial to the mycoplasma research community, saving them valuable time and effort.

In the subsequent months, as our project neared completion, we successfully developed a mycoplasma cell-free extract capable of in vitro transcription and translation, culminating in a 2023 publication. Armed with this breakthrough, we laid the foundation for a renewed endeavor to construct the world's first living cell from non-living components. Our experiments not only enhanced the efficiency of mycoplasma cell-free extracts but also uncovered key insights into creating synthetic lipid vesicles functioning as mycoplasma cell membranes. Additionally, we gained knowledge on installing a protein secretion system in a lipid vesicle.

With both unexpected and anticipated challenges addressed, we now intend to submit a new proposal to the National Science Foundation. Success in this endeavor could catalyze a rapid expansion of the synthetic cell field, unlocking valuable discoveries with applications in medicine, industry, agriculture, and fundamental research.

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2023
Modified by: John I Glass
